Has anyone written about categories with this property?

Property A. Given morphisms f:x→yf: x \to yf:x→y and g:y→xg: y \to xg:y→x, fff must be the inverse of ggg.

Note that any preorder has this property, and so does any groupoid.

More generally, I believe we can get a lot of categories with property A as follows. Take any preorder PPP and any pseudofunctor F:P→GpdF: P \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:P→Gpd, and do the covariant Grothendieck construction ∫F\int F∫F. Then I believe ∫F\int F∫F has property A. The category ∫F\int F∫F is like a "bundle of groupoids over a preorder".

But I believe it's not true that any category with property A is given by the above construction! A counterexample would a category with only two objects xxx and yyy, two morphisms f,g ⁣:x→yf, g \colon x \to yf,g:x→y, and identity morphisms for xxx and yyy.

This category is not a preorder, but it has a weaker property shared by all preorders:

Property B. If there is a morphism f:x→yf : x \to yf:x→y that is not an isomorphism, there is no morphism g:x→yg: x \to yg:x→y.

Has anyone studied categories with property B?
Hm? Groupoids don't have Property A, do they? Just deloop any nontrivial group, and if you want x≠yx\ne yx=y, cross this delooping with the walking iso.
So Pro A ⇔\Leftrightarrow⇔ endomorphisms are identities ?
And if there is typo in Pro B (where g:y→xg:y \to xg:y→x), then it looks like Pro B ⇔\Leftrightarrow⇔ endomorphisms are isomorphisms (by contradiction)

So looks like we have an inclusion Pro(A)↪Pro(B)\mathbf{Pro}(A) \hookrightarrow \mathbf{Pro}(B)Pro(A)↪Pro(B) and we have a functor (is it?) Pro(B)→Pro(A)\mathbf{Pro}(B) \to \mathbf{Pro}(A)Pro(B)→Pro(A) which maps a category CCC to a category C′C'C′ where C′C'C′ is defined as:

  • Objects: Obj(C′)=Obj(C)\mathsf{Obj}(C') = \mathsf{Obj}(C)Obj(C′)=Obj(C)
  • Arrows: for every arrow fff in C(x,y)C(x,y)C(x,y), we impose that C′(x,y)C'(x,y)C′(x,y) contains:

[f]={g ∣ h∘g=f∘h′ ,∃ h,h′ automorphisms }[f] = \{ g ~| ~h \circ g = f \circ h'\,, \exists\, h, h' \textrm{ automorphisms }\}[f]={g ∣ h∘g=f∘h′,∃h,h′ automorphisms }

Here g∈[f]g \in [f]g∈[f] defines a relation g∼fg \sim fg∼f where ∼\sim∼ is an equivalence:

  • symmetry: use the inverse
  • reflexive: id\mathsf{id}id
  • transitive: transfer the automorphisms

and we have:

[f]∘[f′]=[f∘f′][f] \circ [f'] = [f \circ f'][f]∘[f′]=[f∘f′]

I would probably look into functors like Pro(B)→Prop(A)\mathbf{Pro}(B) \to \mathbf{Prop}(A)Pro(B)→Prop(A), because they might hide some equivalence/adjunction which would help express any category CCC in Pro(B)\mathbf{Pro}(B)Pro(B) in terms of its corresponding category C′C'C′ in Pro(A)\mathbf{Pro}(A)Pro(A), which could be close to a preorder, if not one.

Haha, yes it is! As you can see, I haven't put much thought into this yet. Property A is stricter than I want - what I want is property A', which is the same as property B.

It would be nice to have a construction of all categories with property A' as some sort of hybrid of a preorder and a groupoid.

Property B: given morphisms f:x→yf : x \to yf:x→y and g:y→xg: y \to xg:y→x, both fff and ggg are isomorphisms.

EI-category: every endomorphism is an isomorphism.

@Rémy Tuyéras suggested that these are equivalent. I easily saw that every category with property B is an EI-category, but I didn't believe the reverse implication until I looked at the nLab, which offers a proof.

The proof uses the (claimed) fact that isomorphisms obey the two-out-of-six property.

I say "claimed" because I still haven't shown to myself that they do!

(I haven't tried yet. It seems like a surprising fact, but someday it should seem obvious.)

It should be something like this?

fgfgfg has a right inverse ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ fff has a right inverse, gfgfgf has a left inverse ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ fff has a left inverse, and if something is right and left invertible then it is invertible and the left and right inverses agree.
Why does fgfgfg having a right inverse imply that fff has a right inverse? (Simple enough, but this is the key step in my opinion. Symmetry will then handle the left inverses, etc.)

Okay, so it's [[EI categories]] that I'm interested in. I suppose I should say why:

Proposition The category of finite-dimensional simple algebras over a field (with algebra homomorphisms as morphisms) is an EI-category.

Proof. Suppose AAA is a finite-dimensional simple algebra and f ⁣:A→Af\colon A \to Af:A→A is an endomorphism. The kernel of fff is an ideal of AAA, but since AAA is simple, by definition its only ideals are {0}\{0\}{0} and AAA. Suppose AAA has 1≠01 \ne 01=0. Then the kernel of fff can't be all of AAA since f(1)=1≠0f(1) = 1 \ne 0f(1)=1=0, so the kernel is {0}\{0\}{0}. Thus fff is one-to-one, so by dimension-counting it must also be onto. On the other hand if 1=01 = 01=0 in AAA then A={0}A = \{0\}A={0} and every endomorphism is automatically an isomorphism. ▮

I hadn't expected to fuss over the algebra {0}\{0\}{0}, but according to the definition I just gave, a standard definition, it's simple! One might argue it's [[too simple to be simple]].

It would be nice to generalize this to simple algebras over a commutative ring. I guess finite-dimensionality condition should get replaced by something like being [[Artinian]]?

It would also be nice to generalize this even further to some class of "simple monoids" in a suitably nice symmetric monoidal category, but for now I will just work with algebras over a field to keep things simple.

The main thing is that we get an EI-category. Let CCC be any EI-category. @Morgan Rogers (he/him) mentioned the preorder reflection C‾\underline{C}C​ of CCC, and this is exactly the road I want to go down. Recall that C‾\underline{C}C​ is the preorder with objects of CCC as elements and c≤c′c \le c'c≤c′ iff there exists a morphism f:c→c′f: c \to c'f:c→c′ in CCC. There's an obvious functor

π ⁣:C→C‾\pi \colon C \to \underline{C}π:C→C​

and Morgan noted that if π(f)\pi(f)π(f) is an isomorphism fff must be too... given that CCC is an EI-category.

Note the fibers of π\piπ are groupoids, because CCC is an EI-category.

I would like π\piπ to be an opfibration and for it to arise via the Grothendieck construction from some pseudofunctor

F ⁣:C‾→Gpd F \colon \underline{C} \to \mathbf{Gpd} F:C​→Gpd

but I may be wrong here.

Since I'm pestering @Alex Kreitzberg to pose precise questions, here is one:

Question. Given an [[EI-category]] CCC is the obvious functor from CCC to its preorder reflection an opfibration?

Okay, I think the answer is no because we can take CCC to the category with two objects xxx and yyy and two morphisms f,gf,gf,g from xxx to yyy (together with identity morphisms). Neither fff nor ggg can be a cocartesian lift of the unique arrow from xxx to yyy in the preorder reflection of CCC.

However, I feel this situation doesn't happen in the kind of example I actually care about, where CCC is the category of finite-dimensional simple algebras over a field. So it may be that I want some strengthening of the notion of EI-category, where:

given two morphisms f,g ⁣:x→yf, g \colon x \to yf,g:x→y, there exist automorphisms α ⁣:x→x\alpha \colon x \to xα:x→x, β ⁣:y→y\beta \colon y \to yβ:y→y such that g=βfαg = \beta f \alpha g=βfα.

I think this forces the functor from CCC to its preorder reflection to be an opfibration.

F:C→Gpd F : C \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:C→Gpd

I'm thinking that for a category XXX to be of the form ∫F\int F∫F where CCC is a preorder and F:C→GpdF: C \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:C→Gpd, XXX must have this property:

Property C. Given two morphisms f,g:x→yf, g: x \to yf,g:x→y, there exists an automorphism α:y→y\alpha : y \to yα:y→y such that g=α∘fg = \alpha \circ fg=α∘f.

That is, I'm thinking this property is necessary; I'm not claiming it's sufficient.

Any category with property C is an EI-category, but not every EI-category has property C.

Notice that any preorder has property C, and so does any groupoid!

It's the EL-condition that I see in practice: without the El-condition to "cut" infinite loops (e.g., x.f.g = x.f.g.f.g), databases on non-EL schemas tend to be infinite. So we typically recommend first trying to make the schema (quiver of the category) acyclic, and if that isn't possible, suggest the EL-condition.
